awd_titl_txt: MRI Acquisition: High Resolution Optogenetic Microscope
awd_abstract_narration: This Major Research Instrumentation award funds the acquisition of a "High Resolution Optogenetic Microscope," incorporating a confocal microscope and a unique optical stimulation method which will greatly further optogenetic research, as well as other areas of research requiring highly sensitive confocal imaging.  While there has been significant progress in the optical detection of protein function, remote optical control has become possible only recently with the emergence of the field of "optogenetics," which employs native or engineered light-sensitive proteins.  The ability to combine well-controlled patterned light and sensitive confocal imaging greatly enhances efforts to understand neural circuit through improved spatiotemporal manipulation of protein function.  The High Resolution Optogenetic Microscope will also be a large boon to the Molecular Imaging Center (MIC), which serves over 40 research groups on campus and at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory.  The MIC organizes a yearly international workshop which focuses on new imaging techniques and applications, bringing together talented engineers, students, and researchers to exchange ideas and information. The MIC also conducts outreach programs with regional community colleges.  The results of these research and teaching efforts will be broadly disseminated through abstracts and peer reviewed publications, as well as by active participation of students and faculty at professional meetings.

por.por_cntn:
This Major Research Instrumentation award funds the acquisition of a "High Resolution Optogenetic Microscope," incorporating a confocal microscope and a unique optical stimulation method which will greatly further optogenetic research, as well as other areas of research requiring highly sensitive confocal imaging. While there has been significant progress in the optical detection of protein function, remote optical control has become possible only recently with the emergence of the field of "optogenetics," which employs native or engineered light-sensitive proteins. The ability to combine well-controlled patterned light and sensitive confocal imaging greatly enhances efforts to understand neural circuit through improved spatiotemporal manipulation of protein function. The High Resolution Optogenetic Microscope will also be a large boon to the Molecular Imaging Center (MIC), which serves over 40 research groups on campus and at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. The MIC organizes a yearly international workshop that focuses on new imaging techniques and applications, bringing together talented engineers, students, and researchers to exchange ideas and information. The MIC also conducts outreach programs with regional community colleges. The results of these research and teaching efforts will be broadly disseminated through abstracts and peer reviewed publications, as well as by active participation of students and faculty at professional meetings.

This NSF grant was used to acquire a very sensitive, high-resolution laser scanning confocal microscope (LSCM), designed for optogenetic studies in many models. LSCM is a light microscope that acquires 3D images from specimens labeled with fluorescent probes by exciting them with lasers. This can be done in fixed or live specimens, thin cell layers, or whole-mount insects, and many other types of samples. We were able to add an external infrared-pulsed laser (2-photon) with additional funding from another source, in order to further the utility of this instrument, allowing imaging in deep tissue such as brain and tissue slices and in vivo mouse brains. Optogenetics is a new method to study brain function by using light to control neurons that have been genetically altered to respond to different wavelengths of light. This instrument gives us the ability to both manipulate and monitor activity using only light – no need for needles or electrodes. There are currently several optogenetic research studies underway using this instrument as a primary platform for data acquisition, and we expect the first publications to be coming out towards the end of this calendar year.

Due to the high sensitivity, speed, and multiple laser sources, this instrument is the busiest in the Molecular Imaging Center, with over 60 hours per week of imaging time. In addition to the optogenetic research, this microscope is an excellent instrument for many other research studies at UC Berkeley, including size control in Xenopus embryos, details of drosophila gene regulation during development, probing synaptic strength of neuromuscular junctions, neurogenesis in adult murine stem cells, and more.

Many researchers from across campus have been trained on the instrument, including students and faculty from Molecular and Cell Biology, Chemistry, Physics, Engineering and BioEngineering, Optometry and Vision Science, College of Natural Resources, and the School of Public Health. In addition, researchers at UCSF, UC Davis, and LBNL have been able to use this unique instrument in their research. It has proven to be relatively easy to use, train, and maintain. It is a great teaching tool and has been featured at the past four Advanced Imaging Methods Workshops...
